text: There are a lot of different ways that learning takes place on this path. It's not just one way. And sometimes I know we feel that we're spinning our wheels or nothing particular is happening, or even maybe we feel worse as a result of sitting here. But as long as you can answer yes to two questions, you are definitely making progress, although you may only become aware of that later on. The two questions are, in general, do you understand what you're doing here? Okay. That's the first question. You'd be amazed how many people practice meditation that couldn't answer that question. What is meditation? What am I doing here? You need to be able to answer that question. It's not a big, complicated question. Well, I'm cultivating mindfulness and equanimity. Mindfulness is the ability to be precise about the components and subcomponents that constitute any given experience. Equanimity is the ability to not interfere with myself. That is to say, to not interfere with the flow of the senses. We have to interfere with the flow of events often, but unfortunately our ability to interfere with the flow of events has become a subconscious, subtle pattern of interfering with the flow of our own senses. So to unlearn that is to learn equanimity. We're here to cultivate mindfulness and equanimity with some aspect or perhaps all aspects of experience. The second question you have to be able to answer yes to is, are you making some effort to do that? The key term here is some effort. Okay. Only some effort is required. As we sit here, the judging mind tends to come up, I'm not doing it good enough, I'm not doing it enough, etc., etc. There is no good enough or enough. All we can do is on a relative scale be making some effort, not completely giving up. So as long as you can answer yes to those questions, that you have some sense of what this practice is about, and you're making some effort, then you're making progress. Significant progress because of the radical nature of this practice. Any progress at all is significant progress when you're dealing with the conundrum of the ages. Okay. The conundrum of the ages is the mystery of oneness and separateness. Sometimes people practice without understanding the principles behind the practice. They do it just out of custom or blind faith. So if you couldn't explain in simple terms what meditation is about, okay, no terrible thing, but be sure to bring that up in an interview or an online session. Okay. So that you know clearly what you're doing in the simple sense. It doesn't mean that you have to know the subtle, deep things that an enlightened master knows about the nature of meditation. But you have a general sense of what this endeavor is about. Now, there's a word in Pali, sampajanya, which in Sanskrit comes out to be samprajanya, pretty close. It means a sort of clear sense of what you're doing. When a person sits down and meditates, they're supposed to have the qualities of sati and sampajanya. Sati means mindfulness. Sampajanya means that you have a sense of what your purpose is, why you're sitting on this cushion, and a strategy for how you're going to implement that, and you maintain that clarity, that purpose, throughout the sitting. So the cat's much more interesting than what I have to say. For me, too. Now, why is that so? If I was an enlightened master, actually, what I would have to say would be as interesting as the cat. But not because of what I have to say. Because if I was an enlightened master speaking my own internal experience, you probably couldn't understand it. The words wouldn't compute too well. But it would still be very, very interesting. What would be interesting about it is not what I would say, which you couldn't understand, but how I said it. I would be saying it the same way that the cat moves. And so you'd listen enchanted, even though you couldn't understand it. Because it would simply be arising out of the source, moment by moment, just like the motions of the cat. The reason we like the motions of the cat is that the cat is very simple. It just expands and contracts effortlessly. Now, the core of our being is exactly the same, whether you're an enlightened master or in a state of total confusion and suffering. The fact is that the core of the being is still part of nature, just like the cat. All it does is expand and contract effortlessly. However, we're not aware of the core of our being, unfortunately. And so we're only aware of the solidified surface that is suffering. We human beings are very complicated. And we're aware of vast complexity in the universe. One direction that human evolution takes is towards more and more and more complexity. In a sense, there's nothing wrong with that. But everything needs to be balanced. And to balance that aspect of human life where things get more and more complex, we know more and more and more, we have to have an opposite activity. And that's what meditation is about. Lao Tzu, in the Tao Te Ching, said, when you study, you gain something every day. When you cultivate the Tao, you lose something every day. What does it mean? Maybe it doesn't sound so desirable. Well, the trick is, he never said that you couldn't do both at the same time. What does it mean to the process of diminishing? Well, the process of diminishing is the process of simplification. You may be surprised to know that simplificatio in Latin was the word used by Christian mystics in the Middle Ages, who did write primarily in Latin, to describe the meditation process. And when I first read that, it didn't quite make sense. But then years later, it made a lot of sense. We start out with the incredible multiplicity and complexity of our personality and our world. What is a natural way to simplify this? Well, all that incredible complexity and multiplicity can only arise from, moment by moment, from X amount of thinking, X amount, Y amount of feeling, Z amount of smelling, R amount of tasting, etc. In other words, it's linear combinations of six senses. So we go from a seeming infinity to six, or combinations of six. Well, that's already a vast reduction. That's why we could describe this path as becoming intimate with the six senses. These exercises that we do are just ways of becoming intimate with the six senses, of realizing that every experience, however complex, however clear or confused, however pleasant or unpleasant, however bizarre or banal, every experience can only involve some combination of these senses. And once you become intimate with these senses, you know them through and through, then you know every experience through and through. That's a tremendous simplification, but that's not enough. Simplificatio means to make into a simplex. That's not a common word in the English language. We have the word simplify or simplification. Simplification means make into a simplex. What is a simplex? Well, sim means one or single, and plex is fold. So a simplex is something that's one fold, not two fold, not three fold. In other words, a unity is a simplex. So how can we make everything one fold? Well, everything becoming combinations of six is a good start. But now the six have to return to some commonality. If all experiences have in common that they're made up of linear combinations of six, what are the six made up of? Well, they are made up of linear combinations of more and less, of increase and decrease. But increase and decrease seems rather bleak, almost abstract. And indeed, if we just think about it, they are rather just bleak concepts. When you actually begin to get in contact with the fact that sensations get a little stronger, get a little weaker, what you're starting to do actually is get in contact with something that is beyond the senses, something that is beyond the six. The principle of increase and decrease or expansion and contraction or welling up and fading or affirmation and negation, in other words, life and death, day and night, outside and inside, future and past, these are the fundamentals. When we start paying attention to how things move, what we're really observing is an invisible force field that might be called spirit that's reflecting in these combinations of senses. That may seem rather strange, but consider the following. The word spirit, as I always say, came into our language from Latin, spiritus. The Romans merely translated it from the Greek panuma, and the Greeks merely translated it from the Hebrew and Aramaic ruach, r-u-a-c-h if you were to write it in the Roman alphabet. And ruach means breath and wind, the ordinary Hebrew word for wind, like the wind that blows through the trees. What's the characteristic of the wind? Well, it's pretty insubstantial. You can't really see it, yet it's very powerful. Well, how can you know the wind intimately? You can watch how the wind reflects in the leaves of the trees because the movements of the leaves, how they turn this way, turn that way, pull in, push out, that reflects the movement, that reflects the force of the wind. And as you know, the wind is a metaphor for effortless. It has no will, it has no desire, it just blows this way and blows that way. That's how the source creates us moment by moment. That's, in other words, how the core of our being operates, the part that is so deep that it can never be congealed into a fixated cell, the part that's still like a cap that is merged with the flow of nature. It's like the wind. And depending on how stiffly or loosely articulated the leaves are to the tree, one can see, one is able to perceive the delicate movements of the wind to a greater or lesser extent. If you have a species of tree where the leaves are very rigidly affixed to the twigs, it's not going to very accurately or richly reflect the flow of the wind. On the other hand, if you take a tree like the cottonwood tree, where each leaf is very loosely articulated, very loosely connected to the twig, the tiniest breeze and that whole tree shimmers with vitality. And that's why it's the sacred tree of the Sundance, I'm sure, although it's never been stated as such. That at least is my concept. It's sacred among the Plains Indians. And my concept is that when you look at it from a distance, it's constantly reflecting this invisible great spirit, the wind. And in fact, the great spirit in the Sioux language is often referred to as daku shkanshka. Daku means something. Shka means to move. Shkanshka, in the grammar of Sioux, if you repeat a verb, means to incessantly do something. It's called a frequentive form. So daku shkanshka is something that's constantly moving. That's the spirit. And you can see that in the flow of steam in a sweat lodge or smoke leaving a pipe or in the wind reflected through the leaves of the cottonwood tree. At first, our being, the surface of our being at least, is very rigid. So it's not very interesting watching the impermanence. It's sort of, so what? But as we watch it and learn to relax a little bit more, our being starts to become a little less rigid. And then the movement qualities become a little more freed up and more pleasing. And that movement sort of massages us and softens us a little more. And then we can see even more movement. And then we open up to that and it massages us and we soften even more. And this is a virtuous cycle. Until finally the core of our being has been massaged or perhaps kneaded like dough, stretched and pressed, stretched and pressed, or perhaps also pounded, but with equanimity. Sometimes we have to accept impermanence not as a gentle massage but as a pounding. But it becomes a massage if we have some modicum of equanimity. So by being massaged and kneaded and pounded, the core of our being softens enough so that it really becomes loosely articulated. And then the movement qualities of our senses seem to be reflecting something beyond the senses, a mode of activity that is effortless, powerful, deeply fulfilling, and yet absolutely insubstantial. It is no thing like the wind. So as you sit and meditate, if it seems like you're getting beat up, that could be okay. If you can maintain even a tiny bit of equanimity, you're being beaten up, not being beaten down. In Japanese they have a word, tatakiageru. You can't quite translate this into English. It means literally to elevate by beating. Yeah, that's exactly how you have to translate it. To elevate something by beating. So what does it mean to elevate someone by beating? It means that you give them a hard time, but as a result of that hard time, they grow. Now of course, people grow in different ways. And it's important sometimes as a result of a hard time, we grow calluses. And that's not what we mean. The idea is to be elevated. You get beat up and you have equanimity, and so you get softened. And as a result of that, you're elevated. When we get beaten down is when we can't for some reason have any equanimity at all with the beating. So then we get beaten down, we get destroyed. So one way that we learn on this path is just by doing. If you can answer yes to the question, you understand how this path works, and you're making some effort, however feeble, then learning is taking place. Sometimes that learning is in a groping mode. You don't really quite know what you're learning. But you are learning something. You sense that you're moving. And be satisfied with that groping mode. It's not necessary to know clearly exactly what's being learned. Sometimes you sense that you're just moving in the right direction. Basically, the forces that lead us to mature spirituality are threefold. There is the sort of efforts that we make. There is the effect of the environment that we create for ourselves, which means our network of friends, being in a retreat situation, having contact with teachers. We create an environment that fosters. So we have the efforts that we make. We have the environment that fosters. Actually, there's four factors. One is the influence of all others that do this, the Maha Sangha, the great community as it's called. That has an influence that helps us. That's why it's traditional to take refuge in the Sangha, the community. The fact that other people are doing exactly what we're doing now all over the world, not many. Okay, we're in a small minority. Remember, there's an intimate link between the fact that we're in a small minority and the world is screwed up. So don't worry about being in a small minority. But the fact is, people all over the world do things like what we're doing here at this very moment, have done them in the past, will do them in the future, and perhaps in the future it will be a majority. We have no way of knowing. At one time, in tribal time, most people did what we do. So who can say in true post-modern time what things will be like a century or two from now? Maybe it'll be a majority again. In any event, when we meditate, we have behind us the entire lineage of every being that ever sat down and sat down with the radical perspective to transcend condition. And even though it's a minority now, it still represents a lot that have done this. And their influence echoes. Some of you may actually feel it when you sit and meditate. All the shamans and shamanesses and the meditators and the enlightened beings, the spirits from other cultures, sometimes you feel their presence aiding you, saying, it's been done by ordinary people like you, you can do it. Buddha is referred to himself as Tathagata. It means Tathagata or Tathagagata, depending on how you want to parse the Sanskrit or Pali word. Tatha means thus, gata means gone, agata means come. The thus come and the thus gone. So, there's two different words, it's translated two different ways in Chinese, depending on that interpretation. You might say that all the meditators and liberated people of the future are calling out to us constantly, saying, come this way, come this way. And all the ones of the past are saying, go this way, go this way, and we're in between. The fourth force that makes it possible for us to do this, of course, is the power of the source itself. So, we have the power of our own effort. We have the power of the environment that we wisely create. We have the power of all that have done this and will do this. And then we have the gravitational attraction of God, the source, nature, whatever word you want to use. The situation that we wisely create, that's real important. There is no way in creation that I would have continued to meditate during, let's say, the first three to four years of my practice, if I had not been stuck in a monastery in Japan without a way home. And I set it up that way. In other words, I didn't have the moxie, I didn't have the courage, I didn't have the energy, I didn't have any of the requisites to do this practice. But what I did have is I was clever enough to set it up so that I had no choice but to do the practice. That's the only thing I basically had going for me. So be clever. If you're not courageous and you don't have a lot of concentration power and you can't make herculean efforts, then you can still slide under. But you've got to be clever. Set it up so that you can't escape. Sign up for the retreat. I don't care whose retreat it is, as long as it's a liberation-oriented retreat. I think you all know the difference. Liberation-oriented means hardcore. It's designed for the long term. It's mature. That's basically the mark of maturity if you look at theories of developmental psychology, how maturity is usually gauged, and this concept actually goes back to Freud, is the ability to see distant goals and not just see what's in front of your eyes. When you're little, it's wonderful, you flow with nature, but you can only see what's in front of your eyes. If your mommy says you can have candy tomorrow but not now, the difference between tomorrow and eternity is, there is no difference. As you grow up, you get a sense of realistic sense of time. Well, a mature practice is not just to feel good now. There's nothing wrong with feeling good now, but it's primarily designed for feeling good forever at some point. That point may not be now. Sometimes you need a more mature practice. Set it up so that you have no choice but to do a mature practice. Set up your life that way. Do something that you've made that commitment that you can't get out of or that you feel embarrassed getting out of. It's fighting fire with fire, using illusion to fight illusion. That's what one of my teachers used to say, you have to use illusion to fight illusion. So, you come to the retreat, you don't want to be the only one that wimps out. That's an illusion, right? Total ego. But that's an illusion that's going to help you overcome a lot of deeper, deeper, deeper illusions. So, as I say, our efforts, which need not be great, but the cleverness in getting us into a situation where we have to do the practice, the environment, the fact that others have done this, and I encourage you, it sounds mystical, but see if you can feel their influence. It's here. Okay? Very, very strong. And then, of course, there's the pull of the source itself. Now, the pull of the source. If you want to talk about it in theological terms, you can say as the Western religion, by that I mean Islam, Christianity, Judaism, and to a certain extent, certain aspects of the Hindu tradition, as they say, God is constantly reaching out to creation with grace. If you want to look at it that way, fine. That's certainly a valid paradigm. There are other paradigms, other models, that actually turn out to be more or less equivalent. They're basically saying the same thing, at least in my estimation. One is a very, very basic principle of physics, thermodynamics. Systems seek what's called the ground state. You can hardly ask any physicist, okay? You can hardly imagine a more fundamental principle than that. The ground state is the most stable state. For example, the bell and the earth form a system together. If we try to balance the bell like that, very unstable. That's not going to last. Nature won't let that unstable state last. If we balance the bell like this, it's a bit more stable, but sooner or later, something's going to happen. Now, how about this? That's the most stable state it can have relative to the earth. And once it achieves that state, it will tend to stay there. So there's a tendency in systems to seek the, you can see why they call it the ground state, okay? It's like you're on the ground, you've touched the ground. Very interesting, because ground is the word that physicists use. And ground is also the word that Christian mystics use for God. It's good if we understand ground in the sense of you're grounded, in the sense of you have reached what is deepest. You've reached that which gives stability, which gives rest. These are all ways in which ground is a good metaphor. Ground's not a good metaphor in some other ways, because when we think of ground, we think there is a thing called the ground. And somehow we're going to try to get to that place called the ground. But the ground of our being is not a ground, it's not a background. It is the source of space, not in space. So the metaphor breaks down there. So instead of thinking of the ground as a thing, think of it as an activity. An activity that nurtures us by pulling in and pushing out. Just like when we were held by our parents. I believe that even the Protestant theologian Paul Tillich used to refer to God as the ground. He got that term from Meister Eckhart. If you ever want to read a great Christian mystic, read Meister Eckhart. He was a Dominican, same order as St. Thomas Aquinas, but really went in quite a different direction. Lived in the 13th century in Cologne, Germany. But he used that word Grund, or ground, for what mystics experience. So you can say on one hand that God's grace is always reaching out to us. On the other hand, you can say that we're part of nature, and in nature it's natural for any system to seek its ground state. And nirvana, the source, is our ground state. Or another way to look at it, saying exactly the same thing. Suffering is unnatural. Pain is natural, but suffering is unnatural. We weren't created to suffer. We were given pain to fulfill a certain function in evolution. Unfortunately, evolution went a little bit awry. Partially because of the hypertrophy, the overdevelopment of the conceptual mind. Pain turned into a thing called suffering. Suffering is what happens when a person experiences pain without mindfulness and equanimity. Now, the meditative path can be looked upon simply as something that arose from nature to correct the little mistake of nature in allowing pain to turn into suffering. So we retain the pain, but we get rid of the suffering. Suffering is unnatural, so given half a chance, our mind and body will learn how not to suffer. Half a chance means simplify the environment for a significant period of time. An hour, a day, a month. So equanimity is the natural response to pain. And if we, as we sit, we're drawn to a state of equanimity. Actually, in daily life, when we're not sitting, we're drawn to a state of equanimity too. But what happens is we can't learn from it because too much is going on. The environment is too complex. So as you're sitting, you get the effect of statistics, the law of large numbers. A pain will arise, the same pain will arise a thousand times. Well, there's a high probability that a few of those times you'll have equanimity. Maybe you'll just be too tired or bored to resist it. Okay? I'm not being facetious. It might just be that you're just too tired or too bored to resist it. But for whatever reason, you don't resist it, and it doesn't hurt as much. Now, that happens in daily life too, but you weren't there to see it. Now you saw it, or some part of you saw it. Maybe your surface mind didn't even see it, but some part of you saw it more clearly than it would in day-to-day life. Enough of those experiences, then it becomes clear. And as soon as it becomes clear, the deep mind starts to say, Hey, I like the way pain feels with equanimity a heck of a lot more than the way I like the way it feels in the other way, even though the other way is a deep habit. So let's start releasing that habit. So that's another way that we learn. Sometimes we're groping. Sometimes we're clearly understanding exactly what we're doing. And it's like, yes, one logical insight after another. And sometimes we're learning by the law of averages. We're just there to see something that happens spontaneously, but because we were there, or some part of us was there, a learning takes place. So the myriad of complexity of self and world reduces to the simplicity of six senses, and the simplicity of the six senses reduces to the much greater simplicity of the six senses increasing, decreasing, spreading, collapsing, expanding, contracting. Now the seeming infinity of complexity is reduced to the simplicity of two. It either gets more or gets less. But it stays the same sometimes, you say. Even when it's staying the same, there's still the forces of expansion and contraction working. If it stays exactly the same, it's still changing. Something's growing. What's growing? If you watch the flower, if you watch a bamboo, it gets longer and longer and longer in space. You certainly say that thing is growing. Now the sensation doesn't change. A minute later it's the same. A minute later it's the same. A minute later it's the same. But something's changed. The sensation is growing like a bamboo through time. Its time dimension is expanding. Let it. That's all it means. But actually feel it expanding in time and then you'll know. Expansion is there. The basic principles of the universe are there. Even in seeming stability. And the more it expands in time, it doesn't change. It doesn't change. It doesn't change. The more irritating it becomes. The more of a violation it becomes. Why? Because the complexity of your personality is being impeded by the simplicity of that event. You can't do all the things you'd like to do, like think about this, think about that, experience this, experience that. There's just this phenomenon that just is the same moment by moment by moment. So what's happening to your ordinary sense of self? Can't maintain it. Can't do this and that. There's other things in the way. That means the ego space is being contracted. The bigger that this thing gets, except what happens to our ego space every night when we go to sleep? During the dreamless portions of sleep, what's become of the complexity of the self? Collapsed to absolute zero. Sleeping person might as well be a dead person. You could take a cadaver and if you ventilated it on a machine, it would be indistinguishable from a sleeping person. So what's happened to the ego space? Shrunk to nothing. Why? Because you can get some rest. Try to rest with your ego space not collapsing to zero. See what that's like. You'd be in perpetual insomnia. The thing is we're afraid of being awake and our ego space collapsing. It's strange when you think about it. We have to do it every night and we're not afraid of it. We're not afraid of our ego space collapsing universally. On the other hand, we like the idea of being awake during the day. It's called being alive. The strange thing is that we like our ego space collapsing in the service of rest. We like being awake and alert in the service of life. But we're afraid of having our ego space collapse and be awake and alert at the same time. It's sort of interesting. A lot of fear comes up. A lot of confusion comes up. A lot of flavors of violation and irritation come up. If you can work through that, then you can actually experience your ego space being consciously collapsed. It's not all that mystical schmistical. Just wait for something that doesn't change. Let its time grow and let your space shrink. If we really go with that process, we experience a deep rest, a conscious rest. The fundamental principles are there. Expansion and contraction are there, even when things seem completely stable. What about the pressure? What about the solidity? Just something pushing out while something pulls in at the same time. Pay real close attention. Let the part that wants to push in pull out. Pull in, pull in. Let the part that wants to push out push out. It may make it hurt worse for a minute. But then the two forces will interpenetrate, and there will be just space. This thing about letting something expand while you contract, I was doing it just a little while ago. That's maybe why it came up in this talk. My room is right next to the bathroom. After the meal, it's like a sequence of toilet flushes. I was resting, not asleep, but resting, lying down. I started to notice that those toilet flushes seemed awful loud and seemed to last a long time as the water was dripping and whatever. It was annoying me. I said, why is it annoying me? It was annoying me because I couldn't think while the toilet flush was going on. So, okay, that's part of the ego space is to think. The other thing is that there was a tremendous... It caused a sense of confusion and disorientation. I would lose the train of my thought. It's like, who am I, where was I, kind of thing. Then all over my body, there was this subtle feeling of being violated somehow. My pores are being invaded by something external. It's like this icky feeling of almost like defeat and violation. Very subtle, very global, and constantly changing. So, I said, well, what if I don't need to think for a little while? What if I don't need to organize for a little while? What if I'm willing to have that subtle flavor? Pretty soon, it was just like the toilet sound was just like this space opening up, releasing out into infinity. As it got bigger, I would just get teeny, teeny, teeny, teeny. Pretty soon, the whole field of consciousness was just being massaged. It was real pleasant. It could have gone on, I don't say forever, but a long time. Sooner or later, I would have wanted to think about something. But for half an hour or an hour or so, I could abide very happily in the toilet. So, it's something to learn, something to know about. The primordial principles are always there. But that's not yet simplicity. Simplex means one-fold, not two-fold. Now we get into the really interesting stuff. But this is the stuff where I said if a Zen master talked or a really enlightened master talked, it starts to get a little hard to understand. The principle of increase and decrease, expansion and contraction, affirmation, negation. As the substance of our six senses becomes softened, we can really feel each moment of experience, expressing ourselves in terms of these two activities. The expression can happen in one of four ways. It may not make a lot of sense. You can just remember the words for now. That's what I had to do when I first heard Sasaki Roshi talk about this. What is this guy talking about? But I remembered the words. And then later on, much later on, oh yeah, of course. Sometimes you'll be primarily aware of expansion. Sometimes you'll be primarily aware of contraction. They may alternate, though. It may be primarily something that goes out, then comes in, then goes out, then comes in. It'll be like mostly expanding, mostly contracting, or just expanding, just contracting. Sometimes you're aware both principles are acting more or less equally and simultaneously. Something's pulling in, something's pushing out, something's getting bigger, something's getting smaller. Something's speeding up, the same time something else is slowing down. So that's three. If you're willing to surrender to sometimes just being expanded and sometimes just being contracted. When you're just expanded, you're like blown away. It's just more, more, more, more, more, more, more, more, more. You can't orient, you can't figure out more, more, more. And you're blown away, and you're just vast space. When there's just contraction, you're crushed. When it's both at the same time, you're ripped in two. Sounds violent, but it's actually very gentle, the whole process. If you're willing over and over again to be kneaded like dough, even if that takes the form of being blown away or crushed or ripped in two, over and over and over again, then inevitably a time will come, an experience will come, when you've followed expansion, followed contraction, over and over and over again, until you become so intimate with them that you can keep track of them so well, that as you're keeping track of them, you notice expansion's not expanding anymore, contraction's not contracting anymore. And there's an experience of true peace, which is not the peace of having a calm mind. Expansion and contraction are the forces that generate time, space, self, and world. When they act. But what happens when they neutralize, when they don't act? Time, space, self, and world do not arise. And it doesn't matter if your eyes are wide open. There is a moment, or perhaps many moments, and if you're a really developed meditator, many hours, but that takes a lot of meditation. But at least moments, extended moments, when the forces that would be molding the experience that you would be having, don't mold. They stop their activity. They merge. And the two become one, which is a zero. Positive and negative cancel, they neutralize. Zero sounds bleak. Zero is a very unappreciated number. Zero was not recognized as a number. How can you have an amount that's nothing? It's not an amount. We have zero as a number just because we grew up with it. We don't realize that people of former times couldn't conceive of zero as being a number. And, interestingly enough, I guess it's just a coincidence, but it certainly is a synchronicity. Where does the word zero come from? An etymology question. It's obviously a word in the English language. Well, how did it come into the English language? Does it go back to Anglo-Saxon, Proto-Germanic? Is it a loan word from some other language? It doesn't sound like an Anglo-Saxon word. Well, actually, I think it came into English through Italian. Well, how did it get in Italian? It ultimately is a corruption of an Arabic word, the same word that gave us the word cipher. And where does the Italian and other Romance languages, where did they get the word zero and cipher? It's not an Indo-European word. It's an Arabic word borrowed into the southern languages like Italian and Spanish that were under Arabic influence in the Middle Ages. It's from the Arabic sufr, S-I-F-R, sufr. It's that funny Arabic S. I don't know if you know it. Johnny knows. He learned it. There's an S in Arabic that's called sod. It's an emphatic S. Anyway, sufr. And what does sufr mean? Sufr means empty. And where did the Arabs, why did the Arabs call the number zero sufr? Well, you may be aware that our writing system is referred to as Arabic, I mean our numeration, our way, our numerals, our way of writing numbers. We call them, what kind of numerals? Anglo-Saxon numerals? Latin numerals? Roman numerals? What do we call them? Arabic numerals. But they are, they're not, they are indeed the numerals used in the Arabic language, but the Muslims did not invent them. It's part of the heritage of the Muslim conquest of India. The Arabic numerals are in fact the numerals used to write Sanskrit numbers. They are the numerals of India. And they were so much more efficient than the original Arabic way of writing numbers, which was taken from the Aramaic, which was to use letters for numbers, the same way the Greeks did. It's felt that that was, by the way, the major force that held Greek science back. They didn't have a good way to write numbers, neither did the Romans. In India, they figured out a really good way to write numbers. So if you pick up a book in Sanskrit, it's all written in Devanagari alphabet, you can't read anything, but you will be able to read the page numbers. Okay? It's not because they borrowed the numbers from here. It's the other way around. In fact, our whole way of calculating comes from India via the Arabs in the Middle Ages. The Christians picked it up because of the Crusades. The Muslims, the Christians, this is in praise of religious warfare, huh? The Christians, we got it because the Christians went on a crusade against the Muslims. The Muslims got it because they went on a jihad against the Hindus. In any event, the traces of that history are found throughout our language. The word algebra, al-jabr, in Arabic, it means the law of cancellation to balance an algebraic equation. And the now ubiquitous term algorithm, al-khwarizmi was a Persian mathematician who had systematic procedures for calculation, and that got corrupted in the Middle Ages into Latin as algorithm and then algorithm. In any event, the zero was part of the numeration system of India, written either as a dot or as a zero. And what did they call zero in Sanskrit? Shunya. This very same word that the Buddhists used for, quote, emptiness. Like I say, it certainly is an interesting synchronicity because that's how emptiness works. Emptiness is very rich because it is the ultimate simplicity that you experience when positive and negative cancel out. But although it is the ultimate simplicity, it is the simplicity that contains all positive and negative. You add up all the numbers, they add to zero. So all the numbers are present in a sense inside zero. If you experience zero just as zero, that's called nihilism. If you experience all the numbers adding up to zero, that's called enlightenment. That's the rich zero. What happens is we start out with the multiplicity of personality and world. We reduce the multiplicity of personality and world to the simplicity of six senses. Reduce, reductio, means lead back. Source is leading us back, pulling us back. And we reduce the complexity of combinations of the six senses to the simplicity of expansion and contraction. And we ride with that enough until we come to the true simplex, the one fold. The only thing that is one is zero. There's only one zero. In fact, I don't know if we have any mathematicians in the crowd, but if we do, you'll remember what's called the set theoretic construction of the natural numbers. The number zero is that which contains nothing, the empty set. And the number one is the set that contains the empty set. It has exactly one element, that which contains nothing. So, there's only one zero. So, to go back to the primordial oneness means to go back to zero. But the route that you take to zero is what counts. As I say, there are pathological routes to zero. They lead to insanity, depersonalization, what have you, psychopathicness. But there are healthy paths to zero. The one I just described is a healthy path to zero. Then the zero is not bleak. It's very, very rich. As Sasaki Roshi always says, it's pregnant with all things. So, that is one way that we can look upon the endeavor that we're engaged in. Of course, all that's just what you do for yourself. So that you can know true rest. So that you can understand how consciousness works. So that you can be the master of every situation. Although, that's an audacious claim. When I went into the Zen temple, Zen temple in Japan is a pretty damn scary place. You know, like a concentration camp. You may think that this is austere here. But, hey, there's levels and levels and levels. It's a scary place. If you've never been in one, you're scared. Real scared. Especially if you're like 22 years old or however old I was. No, no, I was older than that. 26. So, I had this professor who had arranged for me, Japanese professor, Abe Sensei, Masao Abe. Some of you may have heard of him. Editor of the Eastern Buddhist and English Language Publication on Zen in Japan. But anyway, he had arranged for me to go to this temple. Very nice man. Set this up for me. Because in Japan, everything's introduction. You have to have an introduction. So, he gave me a gift to sort of auspicate my entrance into this Zen temple. It was a copy of the Rinzai Roku, the sayings of Zen Master Rinzai in Chinese, the original Chinese. I thought, gee, that's really kind of him. This is really great. You need that anyway because the Roshi gives a taisho, gives a talk on that. So, you need to have a text of it to look at. I was really scared. That evening, after I was sort of settled in the temple, I opened this. I saw that in calligraphy he had written four Chinese characters in his own handwriting on the cover, on the back of the cover. And they just jumped out of the page. It's like talking right to me. It said, Zuisho Sashu. Zuisho Sashu. Zuisho, every, sho, situation. Sa, be, shu, the master. Be the master of every situation. Why did he write that? Here I'm in freak out, Bill. The last thing in the world that is conceivable is to be the master of every situation. You're not going to be the master of any situation for your first five years in a Japanese Zen temple. You are going to be the un-master of every situation. You're not going to know what's expected. You're going to be a dumb kid. You're going to screw up. You're going to get balled out. You're going to be the un-master of every situation. So why he wrote those characters? He wanted me to start to fathom a sense of okayness and freedom independent of you being able to cope. You might think he was saying, like, be able to cope. That's not what he was saying. He was saying, how could you be the master of every situation when you can't cope? If you understand about expansion and contraction, then you'll understand the point he was making. Okay.

segments.text: There are a lot of different ways that learning takes place on this path.
It's not just one way.
And sometimes I know we feel that we're spinning our wheels or nothing particular is happening,
or even maybe we feel worse as a result of sitting here.
But as long as you can answer yes to two questions, you are definitely making progress,
although you may only become aware of that later on.
The two questions are, in general, do you understand what you're doing here?
Okay.
That's the first question.
You'd be amazed how many people practice meditation that couldn't answer that question.
What is meditation? What am I doing here?
You need to be able to answer that question.
It's not a big, complicated question.
Well, I'm cultivating mindfulness and equanimity.
Mindfulness is the ability to be precise about the components and subcomponents that constitute any given experience.
Equanimity is the ability to not interfere with myself.
That is to say, to not interfere with the flow of the senses.
We have to interfere with the flow of events often,
but unfortunately our ability to interfere with the flow of events
has become a subconscious, subtle pattern of interfering with the flow of our own senses.
So to unlearn that is to learn equanimity.
We're here to cultivate mindfulness and equanimity with some aspect or perhaps all aspects of experience.
The second question you have to be able to answer yes to is, are you making some effort to do that?
The key term here is some effort.
Okay.
Only some effort is required.
As we sit here, the judging mind tends to come up,
I'm not doing it good enough, I'm not doing it enough, etc., etc.
There is no good enough or enough.
All we can do is on a relative scale be making some effort, not completely giving up.
So as long as you can answer yes to those questions,
that you have some sense of what this practice is about,
and you're making some effort, then you're making progress.
Significant progress because of the radical nature of this practice.
Any progress at all is significant progress when you're dealing with the conundrum of the ages.
Okay.
The conundrum of the ages is the mystery of oneness and separateness.
Sometimes people practice without understanding the principles behind the practice.
They do it just out of custom or blind faith.
So if you couldn't explain in simple terms what meditation is about, okay, no terrible thing,
but be sure to bring that up in an interview or an online session.
Okay.
So that you know clearly what you're doing in the simple sense.
It doesn't mean that you have to know the subtle, deep things that an enlightened master knows
about the nature of meditation.
But you have a general sense of what this endeavor is about.
Now, there's a word in Pali, sampajanya, which in Sanskrit comes out to be samprajanya, pretty close.
It means a sort of clear sense of what you're doing.
When a person sits down and meditates, they're supposed to have the qualities of sati and sampajanya.
Sati means mindfulness.
Sampajanya means that you have a sense of what your purpose is, why you're sitting on this cushion,
and a strategy for how you're going to implement that, and you maintain that clarity, that purpose, throughout the sitting.
So the cat's much more interesting than what I have to say.
For me, too.
Now, why is that so?
If I was an enlightened master, actually, what I would have to say would be as interesting as the cat.
But not because of what I have to say.
Because if I was an enlightened master speaking my own internal experience, you probably couldn't understand it.
The words wouldn't compute too well.
But it would still be very, very interesting.
What would be interesting about it is not what I would say, which you couldn't understand, but how I said it.
I would be saying it the same way that the cat moves.
And so you'd listen enchanted, even though you couldn't understand it.
Because it would simply be arising out of the source, moment by moment, just like the motions of the cat.
The reason we like the motions of the cat is that the cat is very simple.
It just expands and contracts effortlessly.
Now, the core of our being is exactly the same, whether you're an enlightened master or in a state of total confusion and suffering.
The fact is that the core of the being is still part of nature, just like the cat.
All it does is expand and contract effortlessly.
However, we're not aware of the core of our being, unfortunately.
And so we're only aware of the solidified surface that is suffering.
We human beings are very complicated.
And we're aware of vast complexity in the universe.
One direction that human evolution takes is towards more and more and more complexity.
In a sense, there's nothing wrong with that.
But everything needs to be balanced.
And to balance that aspect of human life where things get more and more complex, we know more and more and more,
we have to have an opposite activity.
And that's what meditation is about.
Lao Tzu, in the Tao Te Ching, said, when you study, you gain something every day.
When you cultivate the Tao, you lose something every day.
What does it mean?
Maybe it doesn't sound so desirable.
Well, the trick is, he never said that you couldn't do both at the same time.
What does it mean to the process of diminishing?
Well, the process of diminishing is the process of simplification.
You may be surprised to know that simplificatio in Latin was the word used by Christian mystics in the Middle Ages,
who did write primarily in Latin, to describe the meditation process.
And when I first read that, it didn't quite make sense.
But then years later, it made a lot of sense.
We start out with the incredible multiplicity and complexity of our personality and our world.
What is a natural way to simplify this?
Well, all that incredible complexity and multiplicity can only arise from, moment by moment,
from X amount of thinking, X amount, Y amount of feeling, Z amount of smelling, R amount of tasting, etc.
In other words, it's linear combinations of six senses.
So we go from a seeming infinity to six, or combinations of six.
Well, that's already a vast reduction.
That's why we could describe this path as becoming intimate with the six senses.
These exercises that we do are just ways of becoming intimate with the six senses,
of realizing that every experience, however complex, however clear or confused,
however pleasant or unpleasant, however bizarre or banal,
every experience can only involve some combination of these senses.
And once you become intimate with these senses, you know them through and through,
then you know every experience through and through.
That's a tremendous simplification, but that's not enough.
Simplificatio means to make into a simplex.
That's not a common word in the English language.
We have the word simplify or simplification.
Simplification means make into a simplex.
What is a simplex?
Well, sim means one or single, and plex is fold.
So a simplex is something that's one fold, not two fold, not three fold.
In other words, a unity is a simplex.
So how can we make everything one fold?
Well, everything becoming combinations of six is a good start.
But now the six have to return to some commonality.
If all experiences have in common that they're made up of linear combinations of six,
what are the six made up of?
Well, they are made up of linear combinations of more and less, of increase and decrease.
But increase and decrease seems rather bleak, almost abstract.
And indeed, if we just think about it, they are rather just bleak concepts.
When you actually begin to get in contact with the fact that sensations get a little stronger, get a little weaker,
what you're starting to do actually is get in contact with something that is beyond the senses,
something that is beyond the six.
The principle of increase and decrease or expansion and contraction or welling up and fading
or affirmation and negation, in other words, life and death, day and night,
outside and inside, future and past, these are the fundamentals.
When we start paying attention to how things move,
what we're really observing is an invisible force field that might be called spirit
that's reflecting in these combinations of senses.
That may seem rather strange, but consider the following.
The word spirit, as I always say, came into our language from Latin, spiritus.
The Romans merely translated it from the Greek panuma,
and the Greeks merely translated it from the Hebrew and Aramaic ruach,
r-u-a-c-h if you were to write it in the Roman alphabet.
And ruach means breath and wind, the ordinary Hebrew word for wind,
like the wind that blows through the trees.
What's the characteristic of the wind?
Well, it's pretty insubstantial.
You can't really see it, yet it's very powerful.
Well, how can you know the wind intimately?
You can watch how the wind reflects in the leaves of the trees
because the movements of the leaves, how they turn this way, turn that way,
pull in, push out, that reflects the movement, that reflects the force of the wind.
And as you know, the wind is a metaphor for effortless.
It has no will, it has no desire, it just blows this way and blows that way.
That's how the source creates us moment by moment.
That's, in other words, how the core of our being operates,
the part that is so deep that it can never be congealed into a fixated cell,
the part that's still like a cap that is merged with the flow of nature.
It's like the wind.
And depending on how stiffly or loosely articulated the leaves are to the tree,
one can see, one is able to perceive the delicate movements of the wind
to a greater or lesser extent.
If you have a species of tree where the leaves are very rigidly affixed to the twigs,
it's not going to very accurately or richly reflect the flow of the wind.
On the other hand, if you take a tree like the cottonwood tree,
where each leaf is very loosely articulated, very loosely connected to the twig,
the tiniest breeze and that whole tree shimmers with vitality.
And that's why it's the sacred tree of the Sundance, I'm sure,
although it's never been stated as such.
That at least is my concept.
It's sacred among the Plains Indians.
And my concept is that when you look at it from a distance,
it's constantly reflecting this invisible great spirit, the wind.
And in fact, the great spirit in the Sioux language is often referred to as
daku shkanshka.
Daku means something.
Shka means to move.
Shkanshka, in the grammar of Sioux, if you repeat a verb,
means to incessantly do something.
It's called a frequentive form.
So daku shkanshka is something that's constantly moving.
That's the spirit.
And you can see that in the flow of steam in a sweat lodge or smoke leaving a pipe
or in the wind reflected through the leaves of the cottonwood tree.
At first, our being, the surface of our being at least, is very rigid.
So it's not very interesting watching the impermanence.
It's sort of, so what?
But as we watch it and learn to relax a little bit more,
our being starts to become a little less rigid.
And then the movement qualities become a little more freed up and more pleasing.
And that movement sort of massages us and softens us a little more.
And then we can see even more movement.
And then we open up to that and it massages us and we soften even more.
And this is a virtuous cycle.
Until finally the core of our being has been massaged or perhaps kneaded like dough,
stretched and pressed, stretched and pressed, or perhaps also pounded,
but with equanimity.
Sometimes we have to accept impermanence not as a gentle massage but as a pounding.
But it becomes a massage if we have some modicum of equanimity.
So by being massaged and kneaded and pounded,
the core of our being softens enough so that it really becomes loosely articulated.
And then the movement qualities of our senses seem to be reflecting something beyond the senses,
a mode of activity that is effortless, powerful, deeply fulfilling,
and yet absolutely insubstantial.
It is no thing like the wind.
So as you sit and meditate, if it seems like you're getting beat up, that could be okay.
If you can maintain even a tiny bit of equanimity, you're being beaten up, not being beaten down.
In Japanese they have a word, tatakiageru.
You can't quite translate this into English.
It means literally to elevate by beating.
Yeah, that's exactly how you have to translate it.
To elevate something by beating.
So what does it mean to elevate someone by beating?
It means that you give them a hard time, but as a result of that hard time, they grow.
Now of course, people grow in different ways.
And it's important sometimes as a result of a hard time, we grow calluses.
And that's not what we mean.
The idea is to be elevated.
You get beat up and you have equanimity, and so you get softened.
And as a result of that, you're elevated.
When we get beaten down is when we can't for some reason have any equanimity at all with the beating.
So then we get beaten down, we get destroyed.
So one way that we learn on this path is just by doing.
If you can answer yes to the question, you understand how this path works,
and you're making some effort, however feeble, then learning is taking place.
Sometimes that learning is in a groping mode.
You don't really quite know what you're learning.
But you are learning something. You sense that you're moving.
And be satisfied with that groping mode.
It's not necessary to know clearly exactly what's being learned.
Sometimes you sense that you're just moving in the right direction.
Basically, the forces that lead us to mature spirituality are threefold.
There is the sort of efforts that we make.
There is the effect of the environment that we create for ourselves,
which means our network of friends, being in a retreat situation, having contact with teachers.
We create an environment that fosters.
So we have the efforts that we make. We have the environment that fosters.
Actually, there's four factors.
One is the influence of all others that do this, the Maha Sangha, the great community as it's called.
That has an influence that helps us.
That's why it's traditional to take refuge in the Sangha, the community.
The fact that other people are doing exactly what we're doing now all over the world, not many.
Okay, we're in a small minority.
Remember, there's an intimate link between the fact that we're in a small minority and the world is screwed up.
So don't worry about being in a small minority.
But the fact is, people all over the world do things like what we're doing here at this very moment,
have done them in the past, will do them in the future, and perhaps in the future it will be a majority.
We have no way of knowing.
At one time, in tribal time, most people did what we do.
So who can say in true post-modern time what things will be like a century or two from now?
Maybe it'll be a majority again.
In any event, when we meditate, we have behind us the entire lineage of every being that ever sat down
and sat down with the radical perspective to transcend condition.
And even though it's a minority now, it still represents a lot that have done this.
And their influence echoes.
Some of you may actually feel it when you sit and meditate.
All the shamans and shamanesses and the meditators and the enlightened beings, the spirits from other cultures,
sometimes you feel their presence aiding you, saying,
it's been done by ordinary people like you, you can do it.
Buddha is referred to himself as Tathagata.
It means Tathagata or Tathagagata, depending on how you want to parse the Sanskrit or Pali word.
Tatha means thus, gata means gone, agata means come.
The thus come and the thus gone.
So, there's two different words, it's translated two different ways in Chinese, depending on that interpretation.
You might say that all the meditators and liberated people of the future are calling out to us constantly,
saying, come this way, come this way.
And all the ones of the past are saying, go this way, go this way, and we're in between.
The fourth force that makes it possible for us to do this, of course, is the power of the source itself.
So, we have the power of our own effort.
We have the power of the environment that we wisely create.
We have the power of all that have done this and will do this.
And then we have the gravitational attraction of God, the source, nature, whatever word you want to use.
The situation that we wisely create, that's real important.
There is no way in creation that I would have continued to meditate during, let's say, the first three to four years of my practice,
if I had not been stuck in a monastery in Japan without a way home.
And I set it up that way.
In other words, I didn't have the moxie, I didn't have the courage, I didn't have the energy,
I didn't have any of the requisites to do this practice.
But what I did have is I was clever enough to set it up so that I had no choice but to do the practice.
That's the only thing I basically had going for me.
So be clever.
If you're not courageous and you don't have a lot of concentration power and you can't make herculean efforts,
then you can still slide under.
But you've got to be clever.
Set it up so that you can't escape.
Sign up for the retreat. I don't care whose retreat it is, as long as it's a liberation-oriented retreat.
I think you all know the difference.
Liberation-oriented means hardcore.
It's designed for the long term. It's mature.
That's basically the mark of maturity if you look at theories of developmental psychology,
how maturity is usually gauged, and this concept actually goes back to Freud,
is the ability to see distant goals and not just see what's in front of your eyes.
When you're little, it's wonderful, you flow with nature, but you can only see what's in front of your eyes.
If your mommy says you can have candy tomorrow but not now, the difference between tomorrow and eternity is, there is no difference.
As you grow up, you get a sense of realistic sense of time.
Well, a mature practice is not just to feel good now.
There's nothing wrong with feeling good now, but it's primarily designed for feeling good forever at some point.
That point may not be now.
Sometimes you need a more mature practice.
Set it up so that you have no choice but to do a mature practice.
Set up your life that way.
Do something that you've made that commitment that you can't get out of or that you feel embarrassed getting out of.
It's fighting fire with fire, using illusion to fight illusion.
That's what one of my teachers used to say, you have to use illusion to fight illusion.
So, you come to the retreat, you don't want to be the only one that wimps out.
That's an illusion, right? Total ego.
But that's an illusion that's going to help you overcome a lot of deeper, deeper, deeper illusions.
So, as I say, our efforts, which need not be great,
but the cleverness in getting us into a situation where we have to do the practice, the environment,
the fact that others have done this, and I encourage you, it sounds mystical, but see if you can feel their influence.
It's here. Okay? Very, very strong.
And then, of course, there's the pull of the source itself.
Now, the pull of the source.
If you want to talk about it in theological terms, you can say as the Western religion, by that I mean Islam, Christianity, Judaism,
and to a certain extent, certain aspects of the Hindu tradition,
as they say, God is constantly reaching out to creation with grace.
If you want to look at it that way, fine. That's certainly a valid paradigm.
There are other paradigms, other models, that actually turn out to be more or less equivalent.
They're basically saying the same thing, at least in my estimation.
One is a very, very basic principle of physics, thermodynamics.
Systems seek what's called the ground state.
You can hardly ask any physicist, okay? You can hardly imagine a more fundamental principle than that.
The ground state is the most stable state.
For example, the bell and the earth form a system together.
If we try to balance the bell like that, very unstable.
That's not going to last. Nature won't let that unstable state last.
If we balance the bell like this, it's a bit more stable, but sooner or later, something's going to happen.
Now, how about this? That's the most stable state it can have relative to the earth.
And once it achieves that state, it will tend to stay there.
So there's a tendency in systems to seek the, you can see why they call it the ground state, okay?
It's like you're on the ground, you've touched the ground.
Very interesting, because ground is the word that physicists use.
And ground is also the word that Christian mystics use for God.
It's good if we understand ground in the sense of you're grounded, in the sense of you have reached what is deepest.
You've reached that which gives stability, which gives rest.
These are all ways in which ground is a good metaphor.
Ground's not a good metaphor in some other ways, because when we think of ground, we think there is a thing called the ground.
And somehow we're going to try to get to that place called the ground.
But the ground of our being is not a ground, it's not a background.
It is the source of space, not in space. So the metaphor breaks down there.
So instead of thinking of the ground as a thing, think of it as an activity.
An activity that nurtures us by pulling in and pushing out.
Just like when we were held by our parents.
I believe that even the Protestant theologian Paul Tillich used to refer to God as the ground.
He got that term from Meister Eckhart. If you ever want to read a great Christian mystic, read Meister Eckhart.
He was a Dominican, same order as St. Thomas Aquinas, but really went in quite a different direction.
Lived in the 13th century in Cologne, Germany.
But he used that word Grund, or ground, for what mystics experience.
So you can say on one hand that God's grace is always reaching out to us.
On the other hand, you can say that we're part of nature, and in nature it's natural for any system to seek its ground state.
And nirvana, the source, is our ground state.
Or another way to look at it, saying exactly the same thing.
Suffering is unnatural. Pain is natural, but suffering is unnatural.
We weren't created to suffer. We were given pain to fulfill a certain function in evolution.
Unfortunately, evolution went a little bit awry.
Partially because of the hypertrophy, the overdevelopment of the conceptual mind.
Pain turned into a thing called suffering.
Suffering is what happens when a person experiences pain without mindfulness and equanimity.
Now, the meditative path can be looked upon simply as something that arose from nature to correct the little mistake of nature in allowing pain to turn into suffering.
So we retain the pain, but we get rid of the suffering.
Suffering is unnatural, so given half a chance, our mind and body will learn how not to suffer.
Half a chance means simplify the environment for a significant period of time.
An hour, a day, a month.
So equanimity is the natural response to pain.
And if we, as we sit, we're drawn to a state of equanimity.
Actually, in daily life, when we're not sitting, we're drawn to a state of equanimity too.
But what happens is we can't learn from it because too much is going on.
The environment is too complex.
So as you're sitting, you get the effect of statistics, the law of large numbers.
A pain will arise, the same pain will arise a thousand times.
Well, there's a high probability that a few of those times you'll have equanimity.
Maybe you'll just be too tired or bored to resist it.
Okay? I'm not being facetious.
It might just be that you're just too tired or too bored to resist it.
But for whatever reason, you don't resist it, and it doesn't hurt as much.
Now, that happens in daily life too, but you weren't there to see it.
Now you saw it, or some part of you saw it.
Maybe your surface mind didn't even see it, but some part of you saw it more clearly than it would in day-to-day life.
Enough of those experiences, then it becomes clear.
And as soon as it becomes clear, the deep mind starts to say,
Hey, I like the way pain feels with equanimity a heck of a lot more than the way I like the way it feels in the other way,
even though the other way is a deep habit.
So let's start releasing that habit.
So that's another way that we learn.
Sometimes we're groping.
Sometimes we're clearly understanding exactly what we're doing.
And it's like, yes, one logical insight after another.
And sometimes we're learning by the law of averages.
We're just there to see something that happens spontaneously,
